text: Bare as all hell. The trees stripped of their bark and wh like ghosts. Some torn violently from their roots and fel STARK GRAY SUNLIGHT shafts between the trees, clouded by creeping fog that obscures the true color of everything. LIGHT SNOW flutters. The world monochrome, lifeless and c A CAT prowls across the dead earth. Barely recognizable a the domestic breed it might once have been. Its fur mangy rank, body rib-thin from starvation. Entirely feral. It moves slowly, cautiously. Sniffing the air, scanning t forest, alert. Trusting nothing of its surroundings. It p across a leaf-strewn clearing, closing stealthily on: A DEAD MAN, splayed face-down in the earth. His feet bare Face frozen in a grim death mask. A GAPING GUNSHOT WOUND his head, the dried blood caked around it matting his hai As the cat moves closer, approaching warily:
About thirty yards away. Someone is watching. Waiting. SL DEEP BREATHS, heard through a GASMASK RESPIRATOR.

The MIRRORED LENSES reflecting the forest clearing, locke onto the cat. The slow, metered breathing continues. THE CAT slows, but continues pacing toward the corpse. Mo cautious than ever. It inches forward, sniffing at the bo ON THE WATCHER. Crouched behind the mangled stump of a fe tree. Concealed beneath a camouflaging mesh of leaves, tw and bracken. A "ghillie suit" of the kind used by snipers THE CAT sniffs at the dead man's hand, frozen by death in grotesquely contorted claw. The animal still unsure. Look around again, checking its surroundings for predators. THE WATCHER moves almost imperceptibly. The leaves coveri him rustle ever so slightly as we hear - just barely - th familiar creaking sound of a BOW STRING BEING DRAWN TAUT. THE CAT hears it. Looks up, alert. Staring right at the watcher, but he is too well camouflaged to be seen. An interminable, tense BEAT - is the prey going to flee? Finally, the cat turns its attention back to the carcass, nibbling gingerly at the flesh of the man's fingers.

THE WATCHER looses the arrow. It sails across the clearin and SKEWERS THE CAT clean through. It drops to the ground THE WATCHER STANDS, shaking off the ghillie suit, reveali him to us for the first time. He wears a weather-beaten knee-length duster. Hooded swea with more layers beneath that. Torn pants and scuffed wor boots. Everything filthy and battered from years of wear. Along with the goggles, his face remains obscured by a DISPOSABLE PAPER DUST MASK and a CRUDELY-FASHIONED FUR HA with dangling ear flaps that may once itself have been a Around his neck he wears a silver SAINT CHRISTOPHER PENDA hanging from a frayed twine cord. His name is ELI. He shoulders the bow and walks across the clearing. Crouc beside the dead cat and pulls out the arrow. Wipes the bl from the shaft, then reaches down to collect the body. Suddenly the cat SCREECHES AND FLAILS WILDLY! Eli recoils falling backward, stunned, as the cat - MORTALLY WOUNDED FIGHTING TO THE DEATH - bites and claws desperately at hi Eli struggles violently with the cat, wrestling it to the ground and grabbing up a HUNK OF FALLEN BRANCH. He holds writhing animal down and CLUBS IT until it lays still. He sits back, breathing harder than the dustmask will all He yanks it down, revealing the dirty, unshaven face bene Impossible to tell his age, but certainly not a young man For a moment he just sits there. Then bundles up the dead and returns to the mangled tree stump. Folds away his ghi suit into a nearby RUCKSACK which he hauls up onto his ba A canteen dangles from the backpack, a SHOTGUN strapped t its side. Eli reaches down for his final possession - an SAMURAI SWORD in a scabbard which he slings across his ba He gazes up at the sky. A snowflake drifts down and lands his cheek. He reaches up and brushes it away, leaving a B SMEAR on his face. Not snow after all, but some kind of A
Eli emerges from the treeline onto the cracked and ruptur asphalt. Lined by more of those ghostly, stripped-bare tr

He sniffs the air, breathing it in. Checks the road in bo directions. Deserted. A few yards away is the rusted, bur out chassis of a CAR. He heads toward it. The car rests half on the road, half in the adjacent ditc Stripped of its tires and engine. In the driver's seat is MUMMIFIED BODY. A BULLET HOLE piercing its forehead. Eli regards the body dispassionately. Tries the door hand but it's jammed. He yanks on it harder and eventually wrenches it open. He leans in and checks the man's feet. They're bare. No shoes or socks. Eli curses under his bre He leaves the car behind and heads on down the road. As h walks away, we see that the sole of one of his boots has loose, held in place now only by a rubber band.

Eli continues down the road. He ambles along slowly, a ma no hurry. A man who has been walking a long time. The road has since emerged from the forest. Passing now through a wasteland of dead scrub brush and urban junk. The sun beats down from directly overhead. The sky has no color to it, paper-white. The unfiltered sun's stark ligh leaves everything seeming bleached-out, over-exposed. CRANE UP as Eli walks on. On the horizon is the silhouett a CITY. Or what was once a city. Columns of BLACK SMOKE r from within, casting a deathly pall over the skyline. BUR AND BROKEN SKYSCRAPERS jut out like tombstones. Eli reaches a fork in the road and stops. The road he's o appears to wind off in the direction of the ruined city o the horizon. The other fork continues on into the wastela After a brief pause, Eli changes direction and heads off the other fork, away from the city.

Little more than a main street lined with storefronts. El walks steadily along, side-stepping rubble and debris. Ignoring the petrified corpses lying in the street. He passes by abandoned stores, every one picked clean. Em shelves, smashed windows. Looted and burned. He doesn't e look inside, knowing already that he will find nothing. Until he comes to a store that does cause him to stop. An fashioned sign squeaks on rusted hinges in the breeze.

head_text.speaker/title: ED'S SHOES - GENTLEMEN'S AND LADIES' FOOTWEAR

text: He steps into the doorway and pushes open the door. It sw open on its one remaining hinge before splintering away f the frame and crashing to the floor in a cloud of dust.

Eli steps inside. Like all the others, the store has been cleaned out. Shoe racks and empty boxes strewn over the floor. The whole place reeking of dead, musty air. Eli looks around, just to be sure. Drags his sheathed swo idly along the empty racks as he checks them. Nothing. As he turns back for the door, his foot nudges against a box. It's not empty. He crouches down, flips the lid off hopefully... and pulls out a LADY'S HIGH-HEELED SHOE. He strokes the shoe leather with his hand. Shakes his hea grimly, then tosses the shoe back into the box and leaves

On the outskirts of town. In disrepair - peeling paint, broken windows, damp-stained walls - but habitable. Eli stands in the front yard, surrounded by brownish, overgrown weeds. Thinking it over. Turns to face the sett sun. It will be dark soon. He turns back toward the house

The front door is sent CRASHING OPEN with a hard kick, revealing Eli silhouetted in the fading sunlight. The sho unhitched from his pack and held ready. He moves inside. Another dead place. Flies buzzing in the still, dank air. Everything covered in a thick layer of dust but otherwise largely preserved. An eerie snapshot of a world long gone

Every cupboard empty. Eli checks each one, poking around the dark corners with his sword, but finds nothing but du He opens the freezer, checks inside. Empty save for a sma ICEBOX. The lid stuck fast with mildew and gunk. Eli digs it with his grimy fingernails and manages to pry it open. Inside are the wizened, petrified remains of a HUMAN HAND Floating in slimy, discolored water. The smell vile and t enough to make Eli retch. He quickly jams the lid back on

A wooden bedframe stripped clean. The dresser drawers hav been emptied and lie strewn across the floor. Eli moves toward a large walk-in closet and opens the door. No clothes inside - just the near-fossilized corpse of a HANGING BY A NOOSE. Twisting gently back and forth. Unfazed, Eli crouches down and checks the man's feet. An pair of Converse All-Stars hang limp from the man's skele ankles. Eli calmly sets about unlacing them. He checks the size; they're a fit. He upturns each shoe a shakes the old flakes of mummified flesh from them. Disca his ruined boots and puts on the sneakers, laces them up. He walks around, pacing up and down, getting a feel for t new shoes. They feel good. For the first time, he smiles.

Eli sits in the corner, roasting the carcass of the dead over a small CAMPFIRE. He cleans the animal's pelts as he watches it cook. Pokes at the meat with a pen-knife, chec it for done-ness. It appears ready to eat. He clasps his hands together in prayer.
Dear Lord, thank you for your generosity in providing us today with this bountiful feast.
He speaks QUIETLY, his voice barely above a whisper. Even we catch the accent - a RASPY, OLD-WORLD MIDWEST DRAWL, l John Wayne or some other long-forgotten western icon.

Thank you for the many gifts that you have given me. Thank you for your protection and your guidance. Thank you for bringing me this far. I know my long journey's end is near. I ask now only for the strength and the courage to complete the task that you in your infinite wisdom saw fit to bestow upon me over all men. I won't let you down. Amen.
He signs a cross over himself, then uses the knife to saw a chunk of meat. Takes a bite, savoring the taste with gr relish. To him, it's grade-A filet mignon.
Hey. You hungry?
It appears as though he is talking to himself... until a emerges from his coat pocket, whiskers twitching keenly. offers it some meat. The rat gnaws enthusiastically at it

The last of the waning sunlight shafts through the bedroo broken window. Eli rummages through his backpack, pulls o SMALL PACKAGE wrapped in cloth and tied fast with string. He sits back in his corner and carefully unwraps it. It's OLD LEATHER-BOUND BOOK. The binding cracked and pages dog eared, thumbed through a thousand times and more. Eli gazes lovingly at it. Lets his fingers play across th beat-up old leather cover. A cherished thing. He begins to read, half-hidden in the shadows of the fadi sunlight. Silently mouthing the words as he reads them.

Eli closes the book and parcels it back up as before. Replaces it in his pack, then reaches in for something el A CAR BATTERY. Old and streaked with acid stains. Attache a tangled bunch of ELECTRICAL WIRING and JUMPER CABLES. E reaches into his pocket and produces: AN IPOD. Badly beat-up, the case pretty much held togethe with duct tape. But functional. Eli attaches the battery cable to the iPod and places the headphones in his ears. The music plays. Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 20 in D Mino Eli rests back against the wall and pushes the volume way THE MUSIC SWELLS. Eli's fingers dance and swoop in the ai as though conducting an orchestra, as he is transported b the music to another world, a world far from this one.

Sunlight shafts through the window. Eli sits slumped in t exact same position, headphones still in his ears. Asleep The rat scurries up Eli's chest and licks his face. Slowl he wakes, realizing he fell asleep with his music still o Checks the battery. It's dead, drained overnight. He frow He gets to his feet, moves to the window and checks outsi All seems quiet. He loads up his backpack and weapons.
Come on now.
The rat scurries up his leg, onto his duster and disappea into the breast pocket. Eli turns and moves out.
The gate squeaks shut behind Eli as he exits the front ya He breathes in the air, turns to feel the warm morning su his face. Then turns away from it and walks on down the r

The landscape barren and featureless, road lined with dea trees. Eli walks along the warped and broken asphalt. The road is strewn with burned-out cars and debris from a world long dead. A warped metal sign by the side of the r reads: LITTER REMOVAL NEXT TWO MILES BY: "CIRCUIT CITY". Up ahead is a HUNCHED FIGURE by the side of the road. Eli arrives to see that it's a YOUNG WOMAN. Bone-thin, dresse filthy rags. Skin plagued by an unpleasant rash. The SHOPPING CART she was pushing has overturned into a roadside ditch, spilling its contents. Blankets, tins of food, old clothes. She's on her knees trying to gather it She looks up as she sees Eli approaching. Instantly cower from him, raising her hands to protect herself. Terrified
Oh. Please don't hurt me. Here, take anything you want. You want some food? Take it.
She offers him a can of pet food with a trembling hand. E stands there looking at her. His expression impossible to read behind the mirrored goggles.
I'm not going to hurt you.
That's what the last guys said.
Eli bends down and picks up a couple of the cart's spille contents. Steps forward and offers them to her.
Here.
She blinks. Unsure. Cautiously she reaches out and takes
Could you help me? The wheel came off. I can't fix it. Maybe if I could get it out of the ditch. But I can't.

Eli looks at the cart. It has come to rest in the ditch j inches from a THICK BRACKEN HEDGEROW that lines the road. He looks again at the girl. Her faded blouse is unbuttone revealing a little cleavage. Her skirt torn along the leg showing more than a little thigh. Almost deliberate. He sniffs the air. Watches the hedgerow warily. Just like cat he hunted, his senses heightened and on alert. Behind the hedge, THREE ROADSIDE BANDITS are crouched, waiting to pounce. Each armed with a crude blunt weapon. exchange anxious looks. ELI sniffs the air again - then backs away from the girl.
One good thing about no soap any more. You can smell the road agents a mile off.

The girl's face falls as Eli backs up. The three bandits EMERGE FROM THE HEDGEROW, brandishing their weapons. A co of them wear old sunglasses and goggles similar to Eli's. The BANDIT LEADER grabs the girl by a fistful of hair as passes, yanking her painfully to her feet.
Dumb bitch. What did we tell you?
He pushes her away, she crumples to the road in a heap. Eli backs away, but TWO MORE ARMED BANDITS drop from hidi in the trees behind, cutting off his escape, surrounding
What you got there in the pack?
Nothing.
Yeah, that's what they all say. How about you take it off real slow and tip it out so's we can take a look?
BANDIT #2 notices the shotgun strapped to the pack.
He's got a gun.
Shit, it ain't loaded. They never are. Ain't that right, old man? (BEAT) Open the fucking pack or die.
I can't do that.
The bandit leader steps forward aggressively. Now within striking distance of Eli. He grins, teeth filthy and rott
Want us to do it for you? We can get it off real easy after we've hacked your fucking arms off.
Eli remains perfectly calm. And though he speaks with a s even tone, there is something formidable about his voice.

It's real important you boys listen to me and understand. The man I work for, you do not want to cross him. See, I'm under his protection. You stand in my way, you stand in his. And he will cut you down with a righteous fury - through me. For I am his faithful instrument.
BEAT. The bandit leader looks at Eli incredulously... and then LAUGHS. The other bandits laugh along nervously.
What the hell are you, some kinda preacher?
Something like that.

Well I got news for you, preacher man. Whatever kinda God you reckon yourself to be working for, he left these parts a long time ago. He ain't here to protect your ass. Now take off the pack and set it on the ground.
Eli doesn't move, doesn't say a word. The bandit leader t another step forward and shoves him in the shoulder.
You fucking listening to me?
I hear you. You lay that hand on me again and you will not get it back.
The other bandits exchange nervous looks. This is not how it's supposed to go.
All right, I had just about enough of this shit...

He lunges forward, grabs the shoulder strap of Eli's pack If you blinked, you missed it. But somehow Eli has now dr his sword. A RIVULET OF BLOOD snakes down along the blade drips onto the asphalt. Bandit leader's hand is still gripped firmly around Eli's shoulder strap. But it's no longer connected to his arm. SEVERED HAND hangs there from the strap, dripping blood. Bandit leader staggers backward and raises the bloody stu where his hand once was. Looks at it in shock and horror.
What... you just... he just cut my fucking hand off! My fucking hand!
Eli pries the hand loose from the strap and tosses it ont the road as bandit leader's legs give out and he slumps t the asphalt. His eyes dart around, as though confused.
What you standin' around for? Kiss him!
What's he talkin' about, kiss him?
He's in shock. He means "kill him".

A tense BEAT. And then the four remaining bandits ATTACK ALL AT ONCE, weapons flailing. Eli flourishes the sword. A BLUR, TOO FAST TO FOLLOW. But it's clear he is possessed of an inhuman level of skill.

It is over in moments. The four bandits LAY SLAIN IN THE ROAD, blood pooling out onto the asphalt. The bandit leader crawls toward his severed hand, a few y away. Eli steps in and kicks it out of his reach.
I told you you wouldn't be getting that back.
Bandit leader looks up to see the figure of Eli bearing d on him, silhouetted ominously against the sun. He looks f moment like an avenging angel, something not of this worl
Who are you?
My name is Eli.

And with that, Eli runs him through with his sword. He turns to see the young woman slumped in the road, sobb She cowers again as he approaches, certain that she is ne He WALKS PAST HER. Sheathes his sword, then pulls out the shopping cart from the ditch and rights it. The woman wat incredulously as he gathers up her supplies into the cart
Take it and go on your way. And don't fall in with men like these again. No good can come.
She looks at him, puzzled.
Why are you doing this?

Eli says nothing. Walks back to the slain bandits, crouch beside them and begins searching their bodies. He takes a scarf from around the neck of one. Finds a Zip lighter on another, checks that it works and pockets it.

The five bodies are lined neatly in the ditch, half-cover with dirt. The best burial they are going to get. Eli stands before them, head bowed in prayer. He speaks quietly and quickly, a speech he has given many times.
God, the father of mercies, through the death and resurrection of his son has reconciled the world to himself and sent the holy spirit among us for the forgiveness of sins.
The young woman stands a few yards away, watching him, transfixed. She has never seen anyone like him.
Through the ministry of the church may he give you pardon and peace, and I absolve you from your sins in the name of the father, and of the son, and of the holy spirit. Amen.
He turns and walks away down the road, passing the woman.
Thank you. You're... a good man.
There are no good men on the road.
Where are you going?
West.
Can... can I come with you?
He doesn't even turn back to look at her.
No.
He walks on, into the horizon.

Straddling the desert like a giant, crumbling monument to long-dead civilization. Eli steadily climbs his way up. He comes to an abrupt stop as we realize suddenly that th overpass has COLLAPSED at mid-point. RUSTED IRON RODS jut from where the roadway has been severed. Eli just stands there at the edge for a moment, feeling t wind whip around him, his coat fluttering in the breeze.

The overpass's collapsed section is now just a MOUNTAINOU PILE OF RUBBLE that leads down to the road below. Eli steps onto the rubble. About to make his way down whe FREEZES. He hears something. The faintest of sounds. He t cover, peering down at the road beneath the overpass to s TWO PEOPLE walking together on the road. We see everythin from ELI'S P.O.V. - too far to make out much detail, but apparently it is a MIDDLE-AGED COUPLE. The man pushes along an OLD WHEELBARROW covered by a tarp the woman, seemingly his wife, walks alongside. The barro rusted wheel gives out a plaintive, rhythmic SQUEAK. Eli ducks down again as he hears something else. This tim much louder. The menacing growl of MOTORCYCLE ENGINES. FOUR BIKES IN TOTAL. Riding out of the horizon, closing i the couple. They see the bikes coming and panic. Try desperately to steer the barrow off the road. The bikes screech to a halt and the FOUR RIDERS dismount. Brandishing a variety of weapons. The couple make a run f it but they're quickly chased down and tackled to the gro The woman SCREAMS and struggles helplessly as the bikers swarm over the man like a pack of predatory animals. The woman is pulled to the ground and the clothes strippe from her. Eli turns away. He knows what comes next. Eli listens as the woman screams and screams. He reaches his shotgun... hesitates... then withdraws his hand.
It ain't your concern. Stay on the path. It ain't your concern. Stay on the path.

Eli repeats it like a mantra. He clearly wants to interve but will not permit himself to. Instead, he simply sits a waits grimly as the woman continues to scream for help. A then finally, suddenly, is silenced. Down below, the bodies of the man and woman lay dead and bloodied in the dirt. The bikers tear the tarp from the wheelbarrow, spilling its contents onto the asphalt. They ferret through the items, scavenging a few items - w don't see what - and stuffing them into an old cloth satc They leave the rest strewn in the road and ride off in th direction they came, dust pluming in their wake.
Eli waits until the sound of the motorcycles has receded the far distance before emerging from his hiding place.
Eli crouches on one knee before the murdered couple. He s a cross over their ravaged bodies as he mutters a prayer under his breath. Then stands and continues on down the r

More desolate wasteland as far as the eye can see. The ro forks again here. Eli arrives at the junction and stops. The road Eli is on leads further into the west. The other fork heads toward a SMALL TOWN just visible on the horizo A HAND-PAINTED SIGN has been driven into the dirt nearby. words, just a series of CRUDE PICTOGRAMS. A BED. A PLATE FOOD. A WATER FAUCET. AN ARROW points toward the town. Eli pauses, thinking it over. Retrieves the iPod from his pocket. Clicks the button, but no response. He sighs. He turns and heads down the other fork, toward town.

A primitive, sprawling village of tents and barn-like structures. Built from corrugated iron, rotted wood, mold plastic, tarpaulin - materials scavenged from the old wor HUDDLED RESIDENTS are dressed in little more than rags, m wearing goggles like Eli's to shield their eyes from the Eli stands at the edge of town. Reluctant to enter, but h braces himself and walks on in. And as he rounds a corner entering the center of town, an astonishing sight:

The broad thoroughfare now all that remains of whatever t once stood here. Many of the old storefronts still largel intact but patched up with salvaged materials. The asphal street warped and cracked, parking meters bent and smashe It's a lot like the abandoned town Eli passed through earlier, except VERY MUCH ALIVE - BUSTLING WITH TOWNSFOLK It's at once a familiar and also a disturbing sight - lik old Norman Rockwell painting of classic small-town Americ but filtered through the devastating eye of an apocalypse unsettling juxtaposition of the old world and the new.

The centerpiece of the town is a GRAND THEATER at the hea the main street. THE PALLADIUM. Like the rest of the town badly damaged and shoddily fixed-up. But still standing. Eli walks down the street and approaches a BLACKSMITH, hammering out a metal plate over an anvil outside his sto
You got an engineer or a fuelman around here?
The blacksmith doesn't look up from his work but motions toward a storefront at the far end of the street.
Thanks.

Eli heads down the street. Stopping when he comes across STATUE erected in the center of the road. A TALL MAN crud fashioned in clay. One hand placed paternally on the head a SMALL CHILD, the other outstretched toward the sun. As he observes the statue, Eli notices that passing resid take a moment to PAUSE AND GENUFLECT before it. Worshippi Curious, Eli reaches up and runs his hand over the statue face. Then hears SHUFFLING FEET behind him and turns as a PARADE OF EMACIATED MEN AND WOMEN trudges past. Roped together at the waist, each man leading the one behind. Heads shaved, thin from malnutrition. And each one BLIND. They gaze at the ground with pale, dead eyes. They carry picks, shovels and other tools - a sightless CHAIN GANG. Eli watches as the pathetic parade shuffles past, herded cattle by a brutish CHAIN GANG BOSS who swats at them wit stick to keep them moving and indicate direction.
Come on, move it!

The gang boss glares at Eli as he passes by. Eli doesn't return the look, just continues crossing the street as th blind are herded away. Headed toward a wooden building wi pictogram of a LIGHTNING BOLT suspended above the door.

Whatever this place once was, it's now a kind of POST- APOCALYPTIC RADIO SHACK. Shelves display a variety of goo Engine parts. Old electrical wiring. Small appliances. An old ELECTRIC GENERATOR rumbles noisily, powering strin of multi-colored CHRISTMAS LIGHTS that hang all around.

Behind the main counter a convoluted Rube Goldberg-esque STILL is running. An ENGINEER in a leather apron pours th remnants of a can of motor oil into the still's funnel. Attached to the still is an old MOTORCYCLE MIRROR. In its reflection the engineer sees Eli checking out the store. Without turning around, he reaches surreptitiously behind counter for something. Eli turns toward the counter - to find the engineer train a PUMP-ACTION SHOTGUN right at him.
I don't know you.
Eli slowly raises his hands.
I'm not from around here.
No shit. Who are you?
I'm just a customer.
A customer with a shotgun?
He nods toward the shotgun visible on Eli's backpack.
You come in here to rip me off?
The engineer's hands tremble, his finger tight on the trigger. This man needs to be talked down carefully.
No. I'll set it down. Okay?
Slowly!
Eli nods. Unhitches the pack and sets it down, steps away
You carry a gun in the outland, you don't bring one into town less you live there. Don't you know that?
I'm sorry, I forgot. I've been on the road a long time.
This seems to make the engineer more suspicious of Eli.
Show me your hand.
I'm not a-
The engineer jerks the shotgun at Eli nervously.
I said show me your fucking hand!
Eli raises his hand and holds it outstretched, palm faced downward. The engineer watches it closely for any sign of ticks or tremors, but Eli's hand stays steady as a rock.
I'm not one of them.
The sight of the steady hand seems to reassure the engine little. Finally, he lowers the shotgun.
What do you want?
I'm just passing through. I need some help. I can pay.
What kinda help? And what kinda pay?
I'm going to get something out of my pack. Okay?
The engineer raises the shotgun nervously again.
I know, I know. Slowly.
The engineer watches him like a hawk as Eli opens up his and pulls out the car battery. When he sees it, he gasps.
Holy shit.
Eli places it on the counter. The engineer looks it over awe, like it's a priceless historical artifact.
Where'd you find this?
Years ago, in the outland back east aways.
Does it work?
Yeah, it just needs a charge. Can you do it? I got the cables.
Depends if you also got the coin.
Eli pulls the Zippo lighter from his pocket. The engineer picks it up, sparks the flint, watches the flame flicker.
It'll take a couple hours. There's a bar across the street you can wait, they just opened up.
I'll wait here.
You don't trust me?
(SMILES) I don't know you.

This once grand theater have been largely gutted - seats out, fixtures and fittings stripped, curtains ripped from stage. But still, there's a sense of grandeur to this pla Looking out over the stage, a ROYAL BOX - once the most prestigious seat in the house - has been converted into a OFFICE of sorts. Seats removed and replaced by an ORNATE MAHOGANY DESK facing inward, a CHANDELIER suspended above The whole set-up is gaudy and ostentatious - the work of someone who wants to project an aura of power and wealth, has no taste whatsoever. A TALL MAN is seated in a battered leather armchair behin the desk, deeply involved in an OLD PAPERBACK BOOK. The book's cover is faded and partially torn away, the ti still just visible: 7 HABITS OF HIGHLY EFFECTIVE PEOPLE.

The man is OLDER than most we've seen. His skin weathered the elements and by a long life's experience. One of the few people we've seen in this world close to Eli's age - unlike everyone else we've seen, he appears healthy and w groomed. A rich mane of hair, full set of teeth. He wears a tattered SUIT AND TIE. None of it matches, everything scavenged from different outfits and eras. But looks almost civilized. Respectable. His name is CARNEGIE He looks up from his book at the sound of a POLITE COUGH REDRIDGE stands before him. Tall, powerfully built.
What is it?
His accent is like caramel. A RICH, DEEP-SOUTH DRAWL.
Survey team just finished up their inspection. It ain't good.
Carnegie lowers his book. Concerned.
How bad is it?
Pressure is down again, and going by the new rod they sank levels're lower than they've ever been.
Carnegie stands. Thinking. This is bad news.
How long?
Hard to say. Six months, maybe. A little longer if we're careful. But we're already-
Halve the rations.
We just halved `em last-
So halve them again!
BEAT. Carnegie stares Redridge down. Nobody but nobody questions his orders.
You're going to have to say something. Folks were none too happy last time. Gonna be worse now, you can count on it.
Carnegie sighs, rubs his brow. He knows Redridge is right

A LARGE CROWD OF TOWNSFOLK - several hundred strong - has assembled outside the Palladium theater. AN ARMED CREW OF CARNEGIE'S GOONS keeps watch over the crowd. Carnegie stands on a BALCONY above the theater marquee. H treats the balcony like a pulpit, speaking through a MICROPHONE connected to an old PA SYSTEM that carries his words to the far reaches of the crowd.

I want you all to remember how far we've come together. And how far we still can go, if only we believe. When I brought us here to this oasis - this promised land - we knew there would be hardships. Knew there would be sacrifices. But we also knew that we were creating for ourselves a world where we could be safe from the horrors of the forsaken lands beyond our borders.

The crowd listens intently, hanging on Carnegie's every w He is an incredibly charismatic and persuasive speaker - cultivated image and inspiring, confident delivery remind of a TELEVISION EVANGELIST.
And I want you all to remember above all that it is not the water with which we have been blessed that is the true lifeblood of this town... but faith.

This sends a MURMUR OF DISCONTENT through the crowd. Many don't like where they suspect this may be going. Carnegie senses this and dials up his rhetoric - delivering it now with the fire-brand passion of an old-time baptist preach
It is our faith that sustains us, brothers and sisters! Hallelujah!
The crowd is divided. Many return the "Hallelujah" with varying levels of conviction. Others are not convinced. B Carnegie continues unabated, selling it harder than ever.

And mark me, the ultimate validation of that faith is coming! The sacred Word of Our Lord that formed the world before and will reform it once again is coming to this town to bring it succor, bring it nourishment, bring it new life! For the Almighty Himself has spoken unto me and promised it!
Carnegie is such an impassioned and inspiring speaker it' almost impossible not to get caught up and swept away by words. His apparently unshakable belief is infectious.

In the meantime, He has asked us all to be patient. To walk the hard road of the faithful just a little longer. And to do that, we must give just a little more. (BEAT) Water rations will be halved until further notice.

This sends a much broader ripple of discontent through th crowd - this news has not been received well at all. Some still "keep the faith" but many more are perturbed by thi Carnegie motions for the crowd to settle down.
I understand your frustration. The road to salvation is a difficult one - but what lies at the end of that road is a greater glory, beyond anything you can imagine.
A DISCONTENTED VILLAGER steps forward, pushing through th crowd and jabbing his finger angrily up at Carnegie.
We've heard this all before! When are you going to-
Carnegie's goons quickly move in and efficiently SILENCE MAN, removing him from the crowd. Dissent is not tolerate here. Carnegie goes on speaking as if nothing had happene

I know each and every one of you will understand the necessity of this action. It was faith that built this town - and faith that will sustain it even through the dark times that may lie ahead. But it is always darkest before dawn - and the new dawn is coming. (BEAT) May God go with you all.

Carnegie steps back inside, leaving the crowd to talk amo themselves, clearly mixed about what they have heard. As the assembled townsfolk disperse, FOUR MOTORCYCLES roa into town and pull up outside the Palladium. As the riders dismount, one detaches a CLOTH SATCHEL from bike's cargo rack. The four riders head inside. They each have long, straggly hair and brutish expressions. We recognize them now as the BIKER BANDITS who killed the couple on the road under the freeway overpass.

Carnegie emerges into the second-floor hallway from the balcony, mopping his brow. Exhausted and stressed from hi grand theatrical display, and from its mixed reception. Redridge climbs the stairs to meet him.
One of the road crews just rolled into town.
Carnegie looks at his cracked old wristwatch.
Of course they did, the bar's open. Outlanders, always looking for answers at the bottom of a bottle.
Not these guys. (BEAT) These guys say they got something.
That gets Carnegie's attention.
Get them up here now.

What was once a grand, gilded entrance foyer has, like th rest of the theater, been largely gutted. But it's still impressive - a spacious bar area with a grand staircase leading up to a second floor, entrance to balcony seats, FADED OLD THEATER POSTERS still hang from the walls. The place has been shabbily converted into a kind of SALO Old ripped-out theater seats arranged around tables. A FIREPLACE sputters dimly. A MANGY TABBY CAT walks across the straw-laden floor. A d or so CUSTOMERS in the place, a mixed, rough-looking bunc Redridge emerges from an upstairs room and nods to a grou his MEN who are holding the bikers at the foot of the sta

Carnegie checks his reflection in a CRACKED HAND MIRROR, licks his palm and slicks his hair back. He adjusts his t as Redridge's men usher the bikers into his "office". Carnegie wheels around and flashes a smile at them. Just when he gave his balcony address, Carnegie is in performa mode - charismatic and slick like a campaigning politicia
Gentlemen! It's truly a delight to see you again! I understand your latest excursion into the outland has been a profitable one?
The bikers exchange looks. They understood maybe half the words in that sentence. The lead biker - named HOG - spea
We did good.
Well, let's see, shall we?

Hog tips the satchel's contents out onto Carnegie's desk. BOOKS. About a dozen different volumes of all shapes and sizes. Carnegie rifles excitedly through the collection. We see various titles as he sorts through them. Treasure Island. The Da Vinci Code. A volume of encyclopedia. The Diary of Anne Frank. Tuesdays with Morrie. In amongst the books are a few MAGAZINES. An old issue of OPRAH magazine. A torn copy of SPORTS ILLUSTRATED...

...And a NEWSWEEK. The cover graphic illustrates OPPOSING NUCLEAR ARSENALS over a world globe. On one side the STAR AND STRIPES, on the other flags indicating a SINO-ISLAMIC ALLIANCE. The headline reads: "IS THERE NO TURNING BACK?"
No. No. No. No. No.
As Carnegie rejects each book with growing disappointment frustration, it's clear he's looking for a specific volum
It's not here.
These ain't worth nothin'?
When you bring me the book I asked you for, it'll be worth something.
The bikers exchange more looks. An unspoken conversation.

We been doin' this a long time now. Had to make a whole lotta corpses to bring you all these books. You want us to keep at it, reckon it's worth more than a few free glasses of that swill you call liquor.
Carnegie's guards bristle, ready for a confrontation. Carnegie just smiles, always ready to smooth things over.

Gentlemen, gentlemen. I urge you once again to take the long view here. When we find this book - and believe me, we will find it - we are going to build a new world. A world far greater, far more righteous than this one. And you and I are going to be perched right on top of it, looking down upon it, masters of all creation!
As always, his carefully stage-managed rhetoric is delive with the utmost conviction, every word dripping with pass and persuasion. He's a master salesman, a true huckster.
And you know, I think you're absolutely right.
CARNEGIE (cont'd) That is worth more than a few glasses of liquor. A whole lot more.
He steps forward and looks Hog right in the eye. His gaze like a laser beam, utterly disarming.

The book I want is out there somewhere, just waiting to be found. Once there were millions of copies - you only need to find one! Find it and bring it here. And I promise you, you will be rewarded beyond anything you can imagine.

It's impossible not to be swayed by this guy. He's just s full of fiery passion and infectious belief, you almost w to reach into your pocket and hand over your wallet. Hog snatches up his empty satchel.
This better not be bullshit.
He turns and marches to the door, the other bikers follow The guards escort them out, only Redridge remains. Carnegie slumps back into his chair, frustrated, pissed o
Might help if they knew just what they were looking for.
Not one of them can read. How would they even know when they found it?
So how's about you just tell me?
Carnegie and Redridge lock eyes. BEAT.
Two years now you been sending these crews into the outland. Burning up gas we can barely spare. For a goddamn book? What the hell kinda book can be worth all this?
Carnegie ignores him. Stands, walks toward the door. Redr sighs, gestures toward the books piled on Carnegie's desk
What about these?
Put them with the others.
Redridge stands by the marble fireplace, tossing the book into the fire. The flames flicker and leap around the boo as their pages blacken and are consumed by the fire.
Eli watches as the engineer charges the battery with the generator, which chugs noisily. He licks his lips, dry as sand. Unscrews his canteen to t a drink, but it's down to its last few drips.
What's this place across the street? They got any water?
We got our own underground spring here. Only fresh water in a hundred miles - if's you can pay for it.
Eli thinks a while longer. Then stands and stuffs his sho inside his pack, shoulders his gear and makes for the doo
I'll be back.
Eli stops in the doorway and turns back to the engineer.

If that battery ain't here when I get back, I will use this gun on your kneecaps and I will put this building to the torch and I will watch it burn to the ground with you alive inside it. So help me God.
And with that he turns and leaves. The engineer gulps. No hint in Eli's voice that he didn't mean every word.
This old second-floor DRESSING ROOM has been converted in bedroom, simply furnished.

A WOMAN stands in front of an old DRESSING ROOM MIRROR, t bulbs around the frame burned-out and broken. She washes face in murky water in an old PORCELAIN BOWL on the dress Her name is CLAUDIA. Early 30s, pretty. She gazes into th mirror as she dries her hands, but it's so cracked and wa it's near impossible to see a reflection. The door opens and Carnegie enters. He still looks steame Claudia doesn't turn to look at him, keeps facing the mir
Is that you, honey?
Carnegie says nothing. Just paces angrily up and down. Finally Claudia turns to face him.
Something wrong?
More books came in from the road today.
Oh? It's been a while.
And it'll be a while longer. Just another pile of useless junk. If we don't find the right one soon - if I can't give these people what they want to hear...
Carnegie trails off, the thought too awful to contemplate Claudia adopts a sympathetic expression, supportive.
You'll find what you're looking for. It's out there somewhere. You just have to have faith.
This seems to anger Carnegie. He wheels on her.
Faith? Is that what you think we're missing around here?
She detects the aggressive tone in his voice and goes qui head bowed. Carnegie moves toward her angrily.
My old man used to have faith. He had it in spades. My mother, too.
CARNEGIE (cont'd) You know where it got them? You know where it got me?
He's in her face now. Claudia avoids eye contact, submiss

Faith is for the weak. It's for them out there, the sheep. This world is what you can see and touch and taste. It's what you make it. All these years with me, you still don't have any grasp of that? What's wrong with you, woman?
He's shouting now, and she's trembling, afraid to speak.
I'm sorry.
Carnegie realizes he's frightened her. He softens.
No, I'm sorry. I didn't mean to scare you. Hey. You okay?
He lifts her chin up, wipes away a tear.
You just get me all riled up with that kind of talk. It's not what I need from you right now. (SMILES) You know what I need right now?

He puts his hands on her lustfully. It's clear she's not the mood, but she halfheartedly responds anyway. More out a sense of wifely duty than reciprocated passion. As they kiss, Carnegie pushes her excitedly against the w and feverishly begins unbuckling his pants.

The original customers have now been joined by the four bikers, who sit at their own table drinking a clear and pungent moonshine-type liquor from a shared jar. Eli enters. All eyes are on him immediately, regarding hi with guarded interest as he pulls up a stool at the bar. The BARTENDER approaches, looks him up and down. Suspicio
Outlander? Let me see-
Eli raises his hand as before. Holds it outstretched, ste
What'll it be?
Eli places the canteen on the bar.
Water.
That's the good stuff. Gotta eat into my own ration to sell it - so I don't sell it cheap.
Eli takes off his scarf and puts it on the bar. The barte takes it and looks it over. Not particularly impressed.
That'll get you maybe half-way.
The bartender spies Eli's silver Saint Christopher pendan
What about that?
Eli stuffs the pendant inside his shirt. No way that's fo sale. Instead, he reaches into his coat and produces the pelts he skinned from the dead cat, lays them out on the
That's the best I got.

The bartender takes a pelt and examines it. The mangy cat leaps up onto the bar and approaches. Sniffs at the pelts with suspicion and HISSES at Eli. Eli shoos the cat off the bar with a wave of his hand. At biker's table Hog watches this, not happy about this. Satisfied with the pelts, the bartender gathers them up a with the scarf, then turns away toward the back room.
Solara!

A TEENAGE GIRL emerges from the back. No older than 16 or Dressed in unflattering work clothes, face grimy, blonde tied back in a ponytail. But even through all this, it's clear she is a strikingly beautiful young woman. The bartender takes Eli's canteen and hands it to Solara along with a RATION CARD he keeps around his neck.
Take this out back and get it filled.

Solara takes the canteen, pausing for a moment to look El and down. Unsure quite what to make of him, but intrigued There's something about him she can't put her finger on.. He doesn't look back at her. She turns and exits.

Solara exits via the Palladium's STAGE DOOR and walks acr the busy street to where TWO OF CARNEGIE'S ARMED MEN stan guard around an ENCLOSURE OF CHAIN-LINK FENCE TOPPED WITH RAZOR WIRE. TOWNSFOLK wait in line with bowls and buckets One of the guards recognizes Solara and lets her cut to t front of the line. He punches two holes in her ration car and lets her inside the chain-link enclosure. Inside is an OLD RUSTED SPIGOT attached to a pipe emergin from the earth. Solara cranks hard on the handle - it tak few pulls before the water comes, and then only at a weak trickle; it will take a while to fill the canteen.

As Eli sits at the bar, a SHADOW comes into view and loom large over him. Hog is standing behind him, glaring, cutt a menacing figure in his armored cycle leathers. Solara senses trouble brewing and moves off, taking Eli's canteen away into the back room.
That was my cat.
Eli doesn't turn. Just looks straight ahead. Impossible t read him behind those mirrored goggles. Utterly inscrutab
Fine specimen.
I saw you push him off the bar.
I didn't push him.
You raised your hand at him.
Sorry. It won't happen again.
The bartender looks at Hog nervously.
Hey, how about another drink, Hog?
That cat's been comin' in here for nigh on two years. It got more right to be here than you. Who the fuck do you think you are?
I don't want any trouble.
Hog grabs him by the arm.
Well, that's too bad, `cause-
Blink. Suddenly Hog's head is pinned to the bar by nothin more than Eli's thumb. Pressed deep into a nerve cluster his neck. Eli leans in close as Hog whimpers, paralyzed.
I know you. Murderer of innocent travelers on the road. You're going to spend eternity drowning in a lake of fire for the things that you've done. Did you know that?
The other bikers stand and approach, the OTHER CUSTOMERS following suit. Eli senses the trouble gathering behind h
You go on back to your table and I'll be on my way. All right?

It's all Hog can do to just barely nod his head. Eli rele his thumb. Hog staggers backward, gasping for breath. Eli stands and makes toward the door, but the bikers and other patrons have moved to block his exit.
You push Hog, you push all of us.
Eli sighs, looks down at the floor. He's been pushed one too many today. For the first time, we see anger in his f
Cursed be the ground because of you. By toil shall you eat of it. Thorns and thistles shall it sprout for you. From the ground were you taken. For dust you are.
The patrons look at Eli strangely. Who is this guy? Eli reaches back and draws the samurai sword. Carves a li in the dirt at his feet with the tip of the blade.
And to dust you shall return.

Carnegie has Claudia pinned against the wall, his pants bunched around his ankles, ass bared as he pounds away at her. Not making love. This is mechanical, loveless sex. Claudia stares vacantly over his shoulder into space as Carnegie thrusts into her again and again. Deeply uninterested, just waiting for it to be over. Suddenly, we hear a CRASH O.S. Carnegie stops and listens
Did you hear that? What was that?
Claudia sees an opening to get out of this.
Maybe you should go check.
BEAT. Carnegie keeps listening. Then comes another CRASH.
What in the hell is going on?

He pulls up his pants, grabbing a RIFLE propped by the do as he rushes out. Claudia just stands there for a moment, then reaches down and pulls up her panties. She moves from the wall and makes her way across the room feeling her way with her hands, gazing off into nothingne Only now do we finally realize that she is BLIND.
Carnegie emerges from the bedroom onto the balcony. Looks down over the railing - and is stunned by what he sees.

CHAOS in the bar below. Eli cutting a one-man swath of ma through the dozen brawlers. Most already lie dead. TWO MO MEN ATTACK Eli and are effortlessly felled by his sword. Carnegie rushes hurriedly along the landing, banging loud on the doors of the upstairs rooms.
Get your asses out here!

ON ELI. Surrounded by the dead, only one man left standin Hog. He backs away as Eli circles him like a predator. Sw held ready, the blade glistening with dark red blood. SOLARA re-emerges from the back room with Eli's refilled canteen. She stops and emits a horrified GASP when she se the bloody carnage laid out in the bar before her. She watches, mortified, as Eli moves toward the helpless, terrified Hog, going in for the kill. Raising his sword.. Suddenly, Solara steps forward and CRIES OUT:
Stop!
Eli FREEZES. Sword hanging in the air, poised to strike. turns his head to where Solara stands behind the bar.
Please don't.
BEAT as Eli considers. He looks back at Hog, still comple at his mercy... and then LOWERS THE SWORD.
Go.
(CONFUSED) ...What?
It ain't for me to judge you. Your time for that's gonna come. Believe me. Now go on. Get out of here.
Hog stumbles backward through the door, into the sunlight Eli moves toward Solara, who stands petrified behind the Reaches out and gently pries the canteen from her loose g
Thank you.

In the exitway, Hog turns back inside, grabbing up a BROK BOTTLE from the bloody floor as he goes. Hog rushes Eli from behind. Solara sees him coming and go to SCREAM - but before any sound can come, Eli flips his sword backward and Hog runs right onto it, SKEWERING HIMS BEAT. Hog just stands there for a moment, eyes wide, froz in shock. His fingers go limp, dropping the bottle. He slides off the sword and collapses to the floor, dead. Eli wipes the sword clean and sheathes it. Looks around a the bloodied, fallen bodies. Then back at Solara.
I'm sorry for all the mess.
As he turns and heads toward the door:
Hold it right there.
Accompanied by the sound of MULTIPLE GUNS COCKING. Carnegie is on the landing, training his rifle down at El Alongside him, FIVE GUNMEN do the same. They've got him c

Carnegie sits at his desk, the huge auditorium and stage visible behind him. Eli stands before him. Around him are other gunmen, who keep their weapons trained on him. Standing at Carnegie's side are REDRIDGE and CLAUDIA.
So, who are you?
Nobody. A walker in the outland.
I've met walkers before. Not a particularly civilized bunch. Some have even taken to eating their own kind, did you know that? You wouldn't be one of those savages now, would you?
Carnegie's gunmen look him over, inspecting him warily.
He ain't got the shakes.
Carnegie's confident gaze remains fixed on Eli throughout
Good. This is a civilized town. Under God. Do you know what that means?
Eli can't help but react at the mention of that word.

It means we have laws here. Laws set down long before any of us ever walked this earth. And one of them is, you don't eat the flesh of your brother. Else you're no better than an animal. And not welcome here.
Eli doesn't respond. Just stands there in Carnegie's gaze
So what's your business here, friend? Walkers don't usually come into town less they want something.
I had a battery needed charging and a canteen needed filling. I didn't come here looking for trouble.
Barely noticeable, Carnegie gestures to one of the gunmen who nods in acknowledgement and leaves.
Well, you sure as hell found it. Do you know who I am?
No.
My name's Carnegie. I own this bar. I own the whole town. You've never heard of me?
That's you out there on the street.
Remarkable likeness, isn't it? You'd never guess half the men who built it were blind. A small tribute from a grateful people. I was deeply touched.
You had slaves build you a monument to yourself?
The mention of that word rankles Carnegie. He walks aroun the desk toward Eli, waves an admonishing finger at him.
Don't call them slaves. That's an old word. I'm not a slaver. I'm trying to help these people.
Carnegie can't help himself - once again he is in his nat element, spinning the argument his way, pitching. Selling

In the outland the sightless are preyed upon like sick animals. Here at least they're protected. They do the essential work others don't want. And in return they eat, they drink, they survive. Last year, a couple of them even got married - performed the ceremony myself. (BEAT) You see, I'm not exploiting these people - I'm saving them! Any one of them is free to leave whenever they wish. But here they stay. And they thank me every single day for their salvation!
An impressive, impassioned performance. He sounds just li an old-school TV evangelist. But Eli is unmoved.
It's none of my business what you do here. Like you said, it's your town. I just want to be on my way.
What's your name, walker?
Eli doesn't respond. Just stands there.
All right, I guess we just call you Walker. Don't see too many folks your age these days. You lived in the world before? You can read?
I read every day.
CARNEGIE
That's good. Good man. We educated folk, we need to stick together, if we're ever going to rebuild this world. People like you and me, we're the future. ELI
What do you want with me? CARNEGIE

Straight to the point. I like that. Fact is, you could be in a lot of trouble. This is a peaceful town. You walk in here, armed, and the next thing a dozen of my good citizens are dead. I've hanged men for less. I could hang you. (BEAT)
Or, you could come work for me. ELI
What? CARNEGIE
I never once saw anyone handle themselves the way you did down there in that bar. I don't know where you learned it, but I sure as hell could use it. ELI
I'm not interested. CARNEGIE
People who work for me can live better than any walker ever dreamed. Real beds, clean water, hot food. Women, even. You could do a lot worse, my friend. ELI
I'm not your friend. And I'm not staying. I got someplace I need to be. Out west. CARNEGIE
West? There is nothing west. It's all gone, a long time ago. ELI
I've been told different.
By who?
Eli doesn't reply. Carnegie smiles, dials up the charm.

All right, look. I'm going to make you an offer of goodwill. Stay the night, think it over. Try a little local hospitality. We'll talk again in the morning. If you're still not interested, you're free to go. No hard feelings.
Thank you for your offer. But I'd prefer to just leave right now. So you can either let me out of here, or I can kill my way out.
The gunmen bristle, exchange nervous looks. Carnegie appe unfazed. He smiles. BEAT. He looks to the gunman at the d
Let him go.
The gunman opens the door. Eli turns and exits.
The engineer stands behind the counter, looking worried. heart sinks when he sees Eli enter.
Oh, shit...
How's my battery?
It's, uh... it's gonna take a little longer than I thought.
How much longer?
It's gotta charge overnight. You, uh, you can always stay here in town, pick it up in the morning.
Eli leans in a little closer. He smells a rat.
You remember what I said would happen if I came back here and you didn't have my battery?
It's right here! It's just gonna take a while longer. I swear.
Eli looks at the engineer. Hard to be certain, but he's pretty sure he's lying. Somebody got to him.

A VIOLENT COMMOTION is heard from down the hall. Suddenly of Carnegie's henchmen comes flying into view as he is TH HARD INTO A WALL and slumps to the floor, unconscious. Eli storms into the box, pissed. MORE GUARDS rush in behi him. Carnegie, seated behind his desk, waves the guards o as he stands to greet Eli, smiling ingratiatingly as ever
I knew you'd reconsider.
Yeah? How'd you know that?

None of the walkers I've seen come here from the outland were ever what you'd call smart. I mean all those years out there alone on the road, some with their brains half- fried from eating each other - it's understandable why you people aren't the brightest bulbs in the box. But I never met one so dumb that he'd turn down a meal and a bed if it was offered.
So you didn't send someone across the street to the engineer?
Engineer? I don't know what you're talking about. If there's something wrong, maybe I can help.
Carnegie is a practiced liar. Much more difficult to read
This is Redridge. He's kind of my right-hand man around here.
Redridge - one of the two men who chased Eli into the roo steps forward. He regards Eli with a distrustful eye.
He'll show you to your room.

Redridge opens the door and ushers Eli inside. It's another of the dressing rooms converted into a bedro less well-appointed than Carnegie's own. A threadbare rug Bed with relatively clean sheets. A sink for washing.
Enjoy your stay. There'll be someone outside your room all night. If you need anything.

Redridge smirks and closes the door, leaving Eli alone. E paces across the room. Finally sits down on the creaky ol bed. Trying to figure out how he managed to get stuck her He unshoulders his pack, sets it down. Lies down on the b It's been a while since he felt a real bed on his back. A KNOCK at the door. Eli gets quickly to his feet.
Hello?
The door opens and CLAUDIA enters. Carrying a metal tub o water in both hands and, atop that, a dinner tray.
I have this for you. Water for washing and some food.
Eli just stands there. Totally unfamiliar with this kind situation, it's been too long. She smiles, embarrassed.
Well... are you going to take it?
Oh. Thank you.
He takes the stuff from her, sets it on the table.
You're very welcome.
We get the impression that Claudia is as unfamiliar with kind of polite interaction as Eli. But she likes it.
It'll be dark soon.
She strikes a match and lights the oil lamp on the table. room is lit by its flickering glow.
Can I get you anything else?
No, thank you.
Well. Have a good night.
As she turns for the door:
You're Carnegie's woman?
Why do you ask?
Just making conversation is all. Haven't had one of those in a while. Not a real one, leastways.
Claudia smiles. Neither has she.
He found me in the outland. I was sixteen, my family had been... well, they were gone. There was just me and my baby.
You had a baby?
I'd met some men on the road. Bad men. They...
BEAT. She trails off, struggling with this unhappy memory Eli gets it, raises a hand reassuringly.
It's all right.

I was on the road for a year after that. I couldn't feed myself, let alone my little girl. And then Bill found us and he promised he'd take care of us. He told me he was going to make a place where we could be safe. And he did. He did all that. He built this whole town. He kept us safe. And he raised that child like she was his own. He's been so good to both of us. He saved us, really.
There's a bittersweet quality to Claudia's words. As thou there is more to the story than she is telling. Eli pulls out a chair at the table, offers it to her.
You want to eat some?
She smiles and sits. Eli sits across from her.
When did you go blind? In the war? You get caught in a flash?
No, I was born this way. I think I'm lucky like that.
Lucky?

It's not like I ever knew what I'm missing. I was already used to being like this by the time... by the time it all happened. So I got around pretty good even when I was on my own. And now it's easy. I know every creaky old floorboard in here, and it's not like I ever go any place else. Bill would never allow it. He worries about me so much.
Again, bittersweet. The sense that Claudia feels trapped. Thinking about it begins to upset her. She gets up.
I should go. He'll be wondering where I am.
Eli stands, escorts her to the door and opens it.
Thank you. I enjoyed our conversation.
So did I.
Eli closes the door, then sits back at the table.
Carnegie washes, looking at himself in the old dressing-r mirror. He sees Claudia enter the room in its dim reflect
You took your time in there. How long does it take to deliver a plate of food and some water?
A subtly accusing tone. It makes Claudia nervous.
He wanted to talk.
Oh? What about?
Nothing really. He asked me what it was like to be blind.
He tell you anything about him?
No. I don't think he likes to talk about himself much.
Yeah, I got that.
Claudia moves to the bedside, begins to undress.
I don't think he's going to change his mind by morning. I don't think he's going to stay.
What makes you say that?
Just strikes me as the kind of man who's of a mind, is all. Doesn't seem like the type to go changing it once it's set.
Well, we'll just see about that.
You saw him. He's not like the others. You won't be able to smooth- talk him and wrap him around your finger like you usually do.
Who said anything about me? (BEAT) I'm sending Solara.
Claudia reacts suddenly to this. Shocked and angry.
You're doing what?
You know how often these walkers get laid? Never. Least not by anything living or willing. Girl like her can be very persuasive.
You can't send her in there with him. He's dangerous, he's a killer!
You went in there readily enough.
That's different. Solara's just a child, she can't-
Carnegie sighs, tiring of this.
