In the process she fal on her butt and flips the corpse over onto its back.

In the other woman's arm, she has a SKELETAL BABY cradled her bosom. It seems to be staring right at Solara. Solara SCREAMS and frantically shuffles backward away fro it. Gets to her feet and runs across the forecourt. She stops by the station shop and rests against the wall, hyperventilating, heart pounding. Trying to get it togeth She inspects the water in the bottle. It looks clean. Unscrews the cap with shaking hands and takes a sip. She SPITS IT BACK OUT, coughing. It's rank. Undrinkable.

Solara enters. Gloomy inside. Comprehensively looted. Emp shelves coated in thick sheets of dust. She moves further in, searching for something, anything. the place has been gutted. There's nothing. She checks th wall of dead refrigerators. Shattered glass, all empty. She's never known desolation and emptiness like this. It' beginning to scare her. She wheels around in a panic.
Hello?
Distant, calling from outside. Solara hears it and freeze
Hello? Can anyone help me?
She runs out across the forecourt, onto the road. A FEMALE FIGURE is hunched by the side of the road about fifty yards up ahead. Hard to see what she's doing from h
Hello? Is anybody there?

Solara starts walking toward her. The woman has her back to Solara. She's on her knees, muttering to herself. Gathering objects up from the road. As Solara moves closer, we see that the woman is struggli with an UPTURNED SHOPPING CART. Stuck in a roadside ditch its contents spilled out next to a few BRACKEN BUSHES.
We see her face now. It's the SAME YOUNG WOMAN from befor The same shopping cart. The same trap.
Are you all right?
The woman looks around, sees Solara standing nearby. She' shocked to see that it's a girl.
Oh. Yes, I'm fine. Thank you. You go along, I'll be okay.
You look like you need some help.
No, really! I'm fine. Really... I need a man to help. Not you. You just keep along. Please.
The woman seems anxious to get rid of her. Tries to indic the threat silently with her eyes, but Solara doesn't get
It'll just take a minute.
She steps into the ditch and starts to haul the cart out.
Really, it's fine! Please!

Too   late. THREE ROAD BRIGANDS POUNCE FROM THE BUSHES. E bit   as brutish and horrifying as the group that Eli kil the   road in our opening. They grab Solara and drag her the   road into the desert, screaming and kicking all the
Let her go! She ain't got nothing!
The BRIGAND LEADER looks Solara up and down lustfully.
I ain't too sure about that.
Solara is reviled by the man. He's filthy, his stench overpowering. One eye missing, just a dark, empty socket. licks his lips, revealing a mouth almost devoid of teeth.
This wasn't the deal!
The brigand leader lashes out and grabs her by the throat
Shut your mouth, bitch. You oughta be grateful you're getting a break.
He releases her. She slumps to the dirt, whimpering.
Never did care much for that dried- up old snatch anyhow.
He looks back to the struggling Solara.
This one, though... this one looks fresh. You a virgin?
She says nothing, just sobs helplessly.
Well, let's find out.

He unbuckles his pants, lets them drop to his ankles. We hear a sound. It's hard to place. Something like a THH The brigand leader is frozen in shock. His face goes pale the blood draining from it. The two bandits holding Solar look at their leader in dismay. Staring down at his crotc A quiet whimper escapes from his lips as he looks down. There is an ARROW IMBEDDED IN HIS CROTCH. What was once d there is now just a bloody mess of mangled meat. More blo streams down his thighs. A real horror show. He staggers backward, shrieking. Hands shaking. Staring d at the awful wound from which the long arrow shaft extend The two other brigands release Solara and whip around, scanning the horizon. They see nothing. One of them has a RIFLE. He unslings it and aims it frantically around. Then they both see it. Coming right at them. The most terrifying thing either has ever seen.

head_text.subj: ELI, WALKING TOWARD THEM FROM THE ROAD, OUT OF THE SUN. H

text: silhouette distorted in the rippling heat. An avenging an He pulls another arrow and draws it back as the rifle ban trains his weapon on him, finger tightening on the trigge Eli SHOOTS. The arrow sails through the air and RIGHT INT THE RIFLE BARREL. The feathers at the end of the shaft plugging the muzzle tight.

Rifle bandit pulls the trigger. The gun EXPLODES, BLOWING HANDS CLEAN OFF. He falls to the ground, screaming. Eli only had two arrows. He shoulders the bow and draws h sword. All the remaining brigand has is a small knife. Th two now square off at arm's length. A hopeless mismatch. BEAT. The knife brigand hesitates, trembling. And then RU ELI WITH THE KNIFE. Eli deftly sidesteps, flourishes the sword. So quick it almost seems like he didn't move at al The knife bandit staggers forward a couple more steps. Hi hand goes limp and drops the knife. And then his HEAD FALLS BACKWARD like a Pez dispenser. Al completely decapitated, but not quite. Blood fountains fr the neck stump as his body falls to the dirt. Eli moves to the other two bandits who lay horribly wound on the ground, but still breathing. He stands over their fallen bodies. They stare back up at him, helpless. He crouches down between them in the dust.
I offer you both one final chance in this life to seek forgiveness for your sins so that your souls may find salvation. Will you say with me the act of contrition?
The brigand leader defiantly spits blood at him.
Fuck you.
Eli sighs. Stands and looks down on him without pity.

Some might think it'd be most fitting to leave you here like this. Let you die slow in the sun. But I know better. I know where you're going. And the sooner you get there, the sooner you'll get what's coming to you.
He plunges his sword into the bandit leader, finishing hi off. Pulls the arrow from his crotch and wipes it clean. He turns to the other man, raising his sword.
Wait!
Eli pauses, sword hovering over him, poised to strike.
I want to say it. I want to be forgiven.
Eli crouches once more by his side.
Repeat after me. Oh God, I am heartily sorry for having offended thee, and I detest all my sins.
The bandit follows along with Eli, mouthing the words quietly. The life ebbing from him with each moment.
I firmly resolve, with the help of thy grace, to confess my sins, and do penance, and to amend my life. Amen.
Amen...

His eyes roll back as his final breath leaves him. Dead. signs a cross over his body, then stands and walks away. Solara sits on the ground nearby, a wreck. Eli approaches gathers her up in his arms. She clings on to him tightly.
You came back for me.
What are friends for?
She laughs, a tear rolling down her cheek. Grips him tigh He helps her up and escorts her back to the road.
This is the deal. You keep up. You pull your weight. You fall behind, I can't help you. Okay?
Okay.
She looks back at the young woman still slumped in the di
What about her?
There's nothing can be done for her.
They walk on down the road.

METAL GARAGE DOORS roll back to reveal darkness within. A PAIR OF HEADLIGHTS fires up. Full beam right at us. A VEHICLE roars out of the darkness onto the street. Heav modified with plate armor and turret-mounted weapons. But original form still recognizable underneath. It's a HONDA ODYSSEY minivan. Once the #1 choice of socce moms, transformed now into an armored personnel carrier. Another minivan roars from the garage behind it. A DODGE GRAND CARAVAN, similarly customized and armed to the teet THREE MORE CARS follow. As eclectic an assortment as you could imagine. A MINI COOPER. FORD EXPLORER. A PRIUS. Eac adorned with plate armor and weapons. In the lead Minivan is REDRIDGE, heavily armed. He nods t the DRIVER, who guns the engine. The fleet of armored vehicles moves out, kicking up a gre funnel of dust in their wake as they roar out of town.

Late afternoon. The sun hangs low on the horizon. We're f from the road. Nothing but scrub brush and a few PRAIRIE BURROWS dotted around. A PRAIRIE DOG pops its head up, scans the horizon. Sniffi the air, whiskers twitching... and is SKEWERED BY AN ARRO Thirty yards away, one of the pieces of scrub brush appea to COME ALIVE. And then we realize it is Eli's GHILLIE SU camouflaging both he and Solara beneath it. Eli casts off the camouflage net and walks toward the dea prairie dog. Solara just stands there, appalled.
You killed it! That cute little thing!
Eli picks up the dead animal by the scruff.
It's good eating, is what it is.

He yanks out the bloody arrow. Solara looks away. When she turns back, Eli is standing right there, holding dead animal in front of her face. She YELPS in surprise a staggers backward, falling on her butt.
That's not funny.
If you're going to be on the road, you can't be picky about what you eat. You eat what's there to eat.
I'm not eating that.
(SHRUGS) More for me.

Eli and Solara sit in the mouth of a desert cave, around flickering campfire. The prairie dog roasts on a spit. Eli digs his knife into the carcass, the blade comes out clean. It's done. He clasps his hands together and gazes penitently at the ground.
Father, we thank you for your generosity in providing us with this meal. Bless this food to our use and us to thy service, and keep us ever mindful of the needs of others. Amen.

Eli carves off a piece of meat. Juicy and succulent. He b into it, teasing Solara by making a show of how good it tastes. He feeds a piece to the rat perched on his should Solara tries to appear uninterested, but she's starved.
What does that taste like?
He takes another bite, thinks on this as he chews.
Tastes like chicken.

She tries to fight the temptation to try it... but she ca She reaches out and tears off a piece. Sniffs at it, take small bite... then quickly wolfs down the rest. Eli smile As she eats, she gestures toward Eli's Saint Christopher.
What is that?
Eli reaches up and touches his hand to it.
It's a Saint Christopher medal.
Who's Saint Christopher? Is he a character from your book?
Eli smiles and shakes his head.

Christopher was a man who lived a long time ago. He wanted to be a good man, he wanted to help people. So he would stand by a river that had no bridge and carry people across. He was a big strong man and there was no one he couldn't carry.
Solara listens, rapt. Eli is a good storyteller.

Then one day a young child came to the river and asked to be carried across. Christopher tried to carry him but he was too heavy. He was just a small boy but he was heavier than any man he had ever carried. The boy explained that he was the son of God, and that he was so heavy because he bore all the sins of the world. After that, Christopher was able to carry him across and when they got to the other side the boy baptized him in the river. And that's how he became a saint. Later on, he was known as the patron saint of travelers.
What is a saint, anyway?
It's someone who spent their life doing good things for others. Enough that God himself took a special interest in them.
Solara looks at Eli tenderly, with admiration.
Someone like you.
Eli looks away, down at the ground. He appears sad.
No. Not like me. Saints ain't killers. And I done too much of that. Spilled too much blood.
BEAT. No words, just the flickering firelight.
Will you read me some more from the book?
It's late. You should get some sleep. Maybe tomorrow.

The fire down to its last embers. Eli sleeps next to his pack, half-hidden in the looming shadows of the cave. His and goggles hung up for the night on the hilt of his swor Solara sleeps nearby... then opens her eyes. Not asleep a all. She looks over at Eli - his face hidden in shadow an impossible to tell if he's asleep or awake.
Eli?

No response. Quietly, she moves forward, kneeling by his side. She opens his coat and checks the pockets. Empty. She goes deeper, peeling back the layers of clothing, stealthily frisking him. She finds something on his lapel hidden under several layers, that causes her to stop. It's a RECTANGULAR PLASTIC BADGE. The red, white and blue colors faded and worn. It reads:

She stares at it for a moment, not knowing what to make o it. Then moves on, continuing to pat him down. Whatever she's looking for is not here. She turns her attention to the backpack. Slowly, carefully, opens it up There it is. THE BIBLE, wrapped carefully in its neat lit package of cloth and twine. She reaches in for it. Suddenly, ELI'S HAND SHOOTS OUT AND GRABS HER BY THE WRIS She cries out, startled. Eli sits up, his face just a dar shape in the shadows. For the first time he appears a lit scary to Solara.
What are you doing?
You scared me! I thought you were asleep.
On the road you sleep with one eye open. I asked you what you were doing.
I just wanted to see the book.
You want to see the book, you ask me. Nobody touches it but me. Ever. Until it gets where it's going. Do you understand?
He's very forceful. She nods, a little afraid of him.
Tell me you understand!
He grips her wrist tighter.
Okay! I understand! Ow!
Eli releases her wrist. Takes the pack from her and close up. Pulls it closer to him and lies back down.
It's no use to you anyway. You don't know how to read it.
Well... now we have the time, maybe you can teach me.
Maybe. Get some sleep.
She lies back down beside him, but doesn't close her eyes She just lies there, watching him.

The sun rises out of the east. And out of the sun comes t FLEET OF ARMORED VEHICLES. Racing side-by-side down the r The lead vehicle comes to a halt. A door opens and Redrid gets out. MORE ARMED MEN emerge from the other vehicles a follow him as he marches into the wasteland by the roadsi The DEAD BRIGANDS are splayed out in the dirt where Eli s them. A FLOCK OF BUZZARDS is picking their bones clean.
He's been here.
Redridge looks at the footprints in the dirt headed from bodies and back onto the road. Two sets of tracks.
The girl's with him.
He moves back to the cars.
Move out!
The other men hold for a moment, still looking at the hal eaten bodies in the dirt. Redridge turns back.
I said move out!
I heard this guy's protected somehow, some... power from up above. That there ain't nothing on this earth can touch him.
He's just a man. You put a bullet in him, he'll go down like any other. I don't want to hear no more of this superstitious horseshit!
Hesitantly, they make their way back to the vehicles. The cars gun their engines and move on down the road, past th abandoned Chevron station. Dust pluming in their wake.

Eli and Solara walk together, passing by a few burned-out buildings. It appears we might be headed toward a town. Solara looks up at the sweltering sun. Then around at her surroundings. Nothing but devastation and decay.
You say you've been walking for twenty-five years. Have you ever considered that you might be lost?
No.
But how can you know? How can you know this is the right way?
I told you. My path has been laid out before me.
Yeah, but laid out by who?
By Almighty God.
Well if this God guy's so mighty, how come it's taking you so long to get where you're going? Doesn't he know the way?
Eli wheels around and jabs a scolding finger at her.
You want to stay on this road with me, don't ever let me hear you take his name in vain like that again.
Solara is surprised by the severity of his reaction.
Sorry.
Eli resumes walking.
God has a reason for everything being the way it is. It's not always apparent to us. But it is his plan nonetheless.
So, is he talking to you right now? Telling you where to go?
It's not like that. It's kinda hard to explain. I'm guided by faith.
I don't know what that word means.
BEAT as Eli thinks on how to explain it.
It means you know something even though you don't know it.
Solara thinks about this, shakes her head.
That doesn't make any sense at all.
It doesn't have to.
They walk on.

On the outskirts of a small town that lies in ruins. Almo every building burned or reduced to rubble. Except for one SMALL HOUSE. The building is damaged and w but in mostly decent condition. It stands out among its surroundings for being the only structure still intact. The windows are BARRED. The outer structure fortified wit SHEET METAL and other custom patch-ups. The whole plot surrounded by a CHAIN-LINK FENCE TOPPED WITH RAZOR WIRE. Eli and Solara crouch behind a pile of rubble nearby.
I don't get it. It looks almost... normal. Like nothing ever happened. How can it still be out here?
I don't know.
Maybe we should look inside. There might be food.
BEAT as Eli considers. Then stands and unhooks his shotgu
Stay behind me.

They approach the house cautiously. Arrive at the perimet fence. There's a gate held in place by a PADLOCK. Eli pulls a pair of BOLT-CUTTERS from his belt and snips padlock free. Swings open the gate with a metallic SQUEAK They move inside, up the garden path. Though the soil in yard is dead, it's been carefully raked and tended. WEEDS arranged in thoughtful patterns, like real flowers.
This is weird.
Yeah.
Eli steps forward, his foot planting on a CRACKED PAVING STONE that shifts almost imperceptibly under his feet. Accompanied by a barely audible SOUND. He looks down.
Shit.
What?

A ROPE NOOSE suddenly whips around their feet, tightening their ankles and YANKING THEM UPSIDE-DOWN INTO THE AIR. E drops his shotgun to the ground. They hang there for a moment, twisting in the breeze. The front door to the house SWINGS OPEN to reveal... AN ELDERLY COUPLE. The woman's gray hair tied into a neat bun. The man bald, squinting through wire-frame glasses. look like the couple from Grant Wood's "American Gothic." Instead of a pitchfork the man holds a 12-GAUGE RIOT SHOT which he keeps trained from the hip on Eli and Solara.
They step outside, regarding their new visitors carefully The man seems more suspicious than his wife. He drags Eli shotgun toward him with his foot, hands it to his wife.
Who are you?
My name is Eli. This is Solara. We're travelers, that's all. We don't mean you any harm.
You cut my padlock. I saw you. Trying to break into our house.
I'm sorry. We didn't think anybody lived here. We thought it was abandoned, like all the rest.
This seems to annoy the man.
Take a look around you. Look at this yard. Does it look abandoned to you?
Clearly he's proud of the work he's done with the pitiful means at his disposal.
No, sir. I... like what you've done with the place.
What's your business here?
No business. We're sorry to have troubled you. If you'll let us down we'll happily be on our way.
The wife steps forward, she's much warmer, less guarded.
George, look at them! They're not robbers or road agents! One of them's just a girl!
Seen that before. Oldest trick in the book.
Oh, stop! It's no trick. Let them down!

The woman glares at him. The husband reluctantly accedes moves to the concealed trap apparatus. Releases the rope, dropping Eli and Solara to the ground in a heap. The old woman helps them to their feet. They shake off th noose from their ankles.
I'm so sorry about my husband. We so rarely get visitors these days, he's suspicious of everybody.
I'm Martha and this is my husband George. Would you care for some tea?
Eli and Solara exchange a look. What the hell is this?

It's like something out of the world before. The interior almost perfectly preserved. Chintzy couches. A mahogany table. A TV set in the corner. Lace curtains. Unreal. Eli and Solara sit on the couch, feeling self-conscious a looking entirely out of place in this cozy environment. George sits across from them on the couch, scowling at th inhospitably. The shotgun resting across his lap. Martha emerges from the kitchen, carrying a tray laden wi tea pot and old china cups. Cracked and faded, but intact She places the tray on the coffee table and sits.
I'm afraid we don't have any cake or biscuits for the tea. They ran out some time ago.
She lifts the tea port and pours into the cups. But it's tea, only water. Somewhat murky water. Eli and Solara sta at the cups, unsure. Martha gestures toward them.
Please.
They raise their cups and take a sip. Martha watches eage It's clearly a thrill for her to be doing something as civilized and elegant as serving "tea" to guests.
How do you like it?
It's.. uh...
It's very good.
Martha smiles, delighted. She lifts her own cup to her li HER HANDS TREMBLE, the cup rattling against the saucer.
Have you always lived here?
For almost forty years now. This home is our pride and joy, isn't it, George?
George just grunts. Not interested in conversation.
We refused to leave, even during the troubles. We said, didn't we George, we said if we're going to die anywhere, we're going to die right here, in our own home.
I don't understand how you've survived out here this long.

Well, George is something of a handyman, aren't you, dear? He did a lot of work on the place, making it safe. We may be old, but we're resilient. We've had more than a few who've tried to take this place from us. Haven't we, George?
Yes. Yes we have.
He stands and moves toward the back door. Opens it up and beckons Eli and Solara to come look.
Eli and Solara stand in the doorway, looking out on the y Solara is horrified by what she sees.
The entire back yard is a GRAVEYARD. Maybe twenty human graves dug shallow into the earth. Some were dug long ago others look like they're very recent.
Are these... graves?
Of course. It would be uncivilized not to bury them. We're not barbarians.
Plus, it's good for the soil.
Come on back inside. I think I might be able to rustle up some sandwiches.
George and Martha go back inside, leaving Eli and Solara gazing at the little graveyard.
We have to get out of here.
They look so sweet... I would never have believed they were killers.
They're worse than that.
What?
They didn't just kill these people. (BEAT) They ate them.
Solara is stunned.
They what?
There's a disease in the outland. Spread by eating human meat. It affects the brain. Dementia, loss of motor function. Did you notice the old woman's hands shaking? She's got it. They've both got it.
Oh my God...
Eli and Solara re-enter. Solara looks at George nervously He's still carrying that shotgun. Martha's voice drifts in from the nearby KITCHEN.
I found some meat for those sandwiches! Are you hungry?
No! Thank you!
We really must be going.
So soon?
An unnerving glint in his eye. Eli moves toward the door.
Yes, I'm afraid so.
As he gets to the door, George moves to intercept. Hard t tell if he's blocking his path or moving to open the door him. A tense BEAT. Martha emerges from the kitchen.
Are you sure you won't stay?
Yes. Thank you again for the tea.
Eli stares George down. Reluctantly, George steps aside. opens the door and escorts Solara outside.
Eli and Solara emerge into the sunlight. Walk down the ga path. And FREEZE IN THEIR TRACKS. THE ARMED VEHICLES ARE COMING. Driving toward them out of horizon in a hazy cloud of dust.
Oh no... it's my dad. It's his men.
Are you sure?
I recognize the cars.
Back inside.
Eli bundles Solara back into the house. George stands in doorway, squinting at the approaching convoy.
George follows them back in, furious.
What did you bring upon us?
George? What's wrong?
A whole convoy of armed degenerates, that's what's wrong! Coming here for them! And they led them right to us!

Martha rushes to the window, pulls aside the lace curtain Outside she sees the armored vehicles SCREECHING TO A HAL The men spill out from the vehicles and take cover behind them, locking and loading weapons.
Oh no they don't...
She rushes across the room, teeth gritted with determinat
Martha, what are you doing?
I finally got this house just the way I want it. I'm not going to let anybody tear it apart!

She goes to the couch and yanks off the seat cushions. Underneath is a WOODEN LID which she throws open to revea A HUGE CACHE OF WEAPONS. Automatic rifles. Shotguns. Pist Grenades. And enough ammunition for everything.
She pulls out an M-60 MACHINE-GUN, slings the strap over shoulder and locks in a CHAIN OF BULLETS. She looks like post-apocalyptic Martha Stewart.
Where did you get all this stuff?
George pulls out an AK-47, slots in a magazine.
Took `em off them who came looking to take the place from us. Built up quite the stash over the years.
He offers a .44 MAGNUM to Solara.
You know how to fire a gun?
My daddy showed me once.
Just like riding a bike.
I never rode a bike.
George sighs, turns instead to Eli.
How about you, you know how to-
Eli is already reloading his shotgun, checking the barrel Readying the weapon in the practiced manner of an expert.
Never mind.
Redridge steps forward, raises a BULLHORN.
We know you're in there! Come on out with your hands up and your weapons on the deck and nobody needs to get hurt.
SILENCE. No sign of activity inside the house. Redridge turns back to his men. Their hands trembling. Th didn't sign up for this, and they're not ready for it.
Redridge turns back to the house. Into the bullhorn:
All right, look. I'm gonna make it easy on y'all. Bring out the girl with the book.
Eli is crouched beneath the window. George and Martha hav taken up positions at other windows, peering out.
That's all we want. The girl and the book. The rest of you's can go your way.
What are we going to do?
BEAT as Eli thinks.
Hand me my pack.
Redridge waits. Still no sign of a response. His nervous gunmen exchange worried looks.
They ain't comin' out. They-

Redridge raises his hand to silence him. Looks up as an UPSTAIRS WINDOW slides open. A CLOTH PACKAGE is tossed from the window. It lands in th dirt outside the perimeter fence a few yards from Redridg Cautiously, he approaches. The package is wrapped in clot and tied up with twine. It looks like Eli's bible. He picks it up and tugs at the twine, untying it. Folds a the cloth wrapping. Looks for a moment in puzzlement at t object, at the words written on the front of it.
It's a MINIATURE CLAYMORE MINE. The small red light on to the unit ILLUMINATES WITH A BEEP. Armed.
Holy shi...
He drops the package in the dirt and races for his life b toward the vehicles.
Get down! Everybody get down!

He dives across the trunk of the Explorer into cover as T MINE EXPLODES, SHATTERING EVERY WINDOW OF EVERY VEHICLE. lightweight Mini Cooper takes the main brunt and EXPLODES cartwheeling through the air, a burning wreck. Redridge looks around. Three men lie dead already. Flamin wreckage all around him. Suddenly, it's a war zone. MACHINE-GUN FIRE ERUPTS FROM THE HOUSE, peppering the vehicles' armor. The gunmen cower behind cover.
Damn you, return fire!
Redridge aims at the house and OPENS FIRE. Inspired by hi example, the others follow. A HAIL OF BULLETS CRISS-CROSS BACK AND FORTH. The house's faded paint facade is shredde
Martha continues firing wildly with the M-60. Screaming a the top of her lungs, loving every minute of it.
Come and get it, you god-damn sons of mother-fucking bitches!
George and Eli also open fire from their windows, periodically ducking to take cover from incoming fire. Solara sits across the room, in the corner, sobbing.
It's all right. We're going to be all right. Trust me.
MORE GUNFIRE splinters the window frame above his head.
You remember what I told you about faith?
She nods. Eli peeks out and FIRES OUT THE WINDOW, dropping one of t enemy gunmen with a crack shot. Ducks back down as the re fire impacts around him.
We're going to get out of this alive. Both of us. I know.
Because God told you?
Because God told me.
Amidst all the chaos and gunfire, George has been listeni to this exchange.
What about us?
He didn't mention you.
BEAT. George chambers a round and RESUMES FIRING.

Redridge's men continue the hail of gunfire. Six of them now, six more still standing. No lessening of fire from inside the house. They're losing. Redridge races between the vehicles, ducking from gunfire until he makes it to the back of the Dodge Caravan. Pops trunk and pulls out a ROCKET-PROPELLED GRENADE LAUNCHER. He sets it on his shoulder, rests on the trunk to steady aim. And FIRES. The rocket screams toward its target, tea through the chain fence and TEARING AN ENTIRE CORNER FROM HOUSE in a fiery explosion.
Filled with smoke. The sounds of COUGHING. Dazed, George pushes his way through the smoke, waving hi arms to clear it. A BLOODY GASH on his forehead.
Martha? Martha!

He finds her lying on the tile floor in what remains of t kitchen. Or at least her top half. The rest of her is gon George slumps to his knees with tear-filled eyes. Takes h wife tenderly by the hand for a moment.

Then the anger returns. He gets up and turns, consumed no a wild fury. Firing with rage over the torn brick wall. H CLIPS ANOTHER GUNMAN IN THE HEAD, killing him. George moves back toward the LIVING ROOM, firing as he go
Redridge moves between the cars again, staying behind cov George's hail of gunfire has them pinned down.
We got any more of those RPGs?
That was it.
Screw this.
Redridge jumps into the driver's seat of the minivan, tur the key in the ignition. Jams the accelerator down with t butt of his rifle, then shifts the transmission into DRIV
Get clear!
The gunmen leap clear as the minivan HURTLES TOWARD THE HOUSE, engine roaring. CRASHES THROUGH THE CHAIN FENCE.

Eli looks up from cover and see the van coming RIGHT AT H He dives clear as the van CRASHES THROUGH THE WALL INTO T LIVING ROOM. It SMASHES INTO THE FAR WALL, finally coming a stop. More dust and debris, more coughing. Eli tries to get up, winces in pain. Puts his hand to his side, it comes back WITH BLOOD. A bad wound.
